did.abstract: Toni Morrison (born Chloe Ardelia Wofford, 1931-2019) was a Nobel prize-winning American author, editor, and Professor Emeritus at Princeton University. The material described in this finding aid consists of manuscripts, drafts, galleys, and proofs of Morrison's novels and other writings; personal correspondence; editorial files relating to Morrison's work at Random House and later publication of two posthumous works by Toni Cade Bambara; academic and teaching files, particularly pertaining to SUNY Albany and Princeton University; working files; press clippings; published books, photographs, audiovisual materials, and awards and memorabilia.
did.physloc: This collection is stored partially onsite at Firestone Library and partially offsite (boxes 105-109; 112-114; 122-226; 230-248; 265-275; 303; 321-322) at the ReCAP facility. Boxes 1-11; 13-19; 22-29; 32-47; 50-56; 59-62; 64-66; 227-229; 280-291; 305-308; 310-320; 323; 325-326 are stored in a special vault facilities in Firestone Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material described in this finding aid consists of manuscripts, drafts, galleys, and proofs of Morrison's novels and other writings; personal correspondence; editorial files relating to Morrison's work at Random House and later publication of two posthumous works by Toni Cade Bambara; academic and teaching files, particularly pertaining to SUNY Albany and Princeton University; working files; press clippings; published books; photographs; audiovisual materials; and awards and memorabilia.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research. Toni Morrison's manuscript material, including drafts, typescripts, galleys, and proofs found in boxes 1-11; 13-19; 22-29; 32-47; 50-56; 59-62; and 64-66 are available only via digital access in the reading room. Material in boxes 280-291; 305-308; 310-318; 320; 323; and 325 will also be available only via digital access in the reading room pending digitization. A small amount of material is temporarily restricted at the request of the collection creator or due to the presence of personally identifiable or other legally protected information. For preservation reasons, physical access to original audio and visual media in a variety of magnetic and optic formats is restricted.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Some material in this collection, particularly found in the Writings and Correspondence series, was damaged by the fire that destroyed Morrison's upstate New York home in 1993. Damage ranges from charred edges to pages missing significant portions or rendered illegible.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. No further photoduplication of copies of material in the collection can be made when Princeton University Library does not own the original. For permissions and copyright questions related to Toni Morrison and her writings, please contact her literary agent, International Creative Management (ICM): litpermissions@icmpartners.com.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Some floppy disks were deaccessioned after imaging due to a lack of archival value. Duplicate papers and audiovisual materials were removed from the collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Other materials relating to Toni Morrison's work at Random House may be found in the Random House records at Columbia University's Rare Book and Manuscript Library.
Original drafts of Toni Cade Bambara's writings and related materials may be found in the Spelman College Archives.

A number of recordings of PEN American Center events in which Toni Morrison participated can be found in the PEN American Center Records (C0760). Online access to these recordings is available through the PEN America Digital Archive site.

arrangement.p: This series is arranged into subseries by genre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of research material, notes, outlines, drafts, galleys, and proofs. Yellow legal notepads contain notes, early draft material, and inserts for later typed and printed versions. Notepads are identified by their first lines, though a single notepad may contain a variety of material, including material relating to other works, correspondence drafts, and other unrelated notes. Corrected typescript and printout drafts often show significant revisions. Material from various stages of the publication process is present, including setting copies with copy-editor's and typesetter's marks, galleys, page proofs, F&Gs (folded-and-gathered pages, in signatures but not yet bound), blueline proofs ("confirmation blues"), advance copies (bound uncorrected proofs, pre-publication, often used for book reviewers) and production/design material with page and dust-jacket samples. Page numbers are noted for paginated material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All of Morrison's novels except Song of Solomon are represented (this material was likely destroyed in the 1993 fire).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Born-digital drafts are also present, see Floppy Disks.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Toni Morrison has required the Library to make surrogate copies of all of her manuscripts (including typescripts and proofs) and diaries (appointment books), including but not restricted to those damaged by fire in 1993. This is for conservation reasons, to prevent damage and deterioration by repeated use. Researchers are required to use digital surrogates in the reading room of the Special Collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into subseries following the original grouping of material. The Office Working Files are divided into roughly chronological files groupings, with Office Working Files I being the oldest and Office Working Files IV being the most recent, although there is considerable overlap between II and III. The Additional Working Files subseries includes additional materials received after the bulk of the papers were arranged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of files maintained by Morrison and her administrative assistants, including Ronaline Saunders, Rene Boatman, and John Hoppenthaler. The first subseries of files concern Morrison's book and writings projects, and include correspondence with editors, publishers, and translators, as well as publicity tour schedules and related material. The office files, maintained at Morrison's offices at SUNY Albany and later Princeton University, document Morrison's activities, including awards, conferences, lectures, interviews, etc., throughout her career as a public figure. The office files also include subject files pertaining to her publishers, literary agency, various professional organizations, and individuals; letterbooks of administrative correspondence sent by Morrison and her assistants, various requests received, and fan mail. The files from Morrison's home office are similar in content to the office working files, but are the primary location of book contracts and royalty statements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes additional working files received after the bulk of the papers were arranged.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged in the order in which they were received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes some ephemeral items as well as theses and dissertations sent to Morrison.
